```{r}
show_pathway <- function(step, add = NULL) {
    elements <- c(
        "Helminth Defense",
        "Mast Cell",
        "IL-9",
        "ILC2",
        "IL-33",
        "Migration Trace"
    )
    pathway <- paste(elements[step:1], collapse = " {{< iconify el:arrow-right >}} ")

    if (!is.null(add)) {add <- paste0(' ', add)}
    div <- paste0('::: {.absolute-pathway', add, '}')

    cat(div, '

', pathway, '

:::
')
}

```

# Helminth Infection and Immune Response {.center}

## Type 2 Immune Response {auto-animate=true}

- T<sub>H</sub>2 cell
- Massive stimulation of antibody production
- **IL-4**, IL-13, IL-5, IL-9
- B-cell class-switching from IgG to IgE
- Eosinophilic and basophilic tissue infiltration
- Extensive mast cell degranulation (IL-9)

## *Strongyloides ratti* {auto-animate=true}

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="40%"}
- Rodent-specific parasitic nematode. 
- Laboratory analogue to human parasite *S. stercoralis*

![*Strongyloides ratti* [@VINEY_2017]](assets/images/s.ratti.png)
:::
::: {.column width="60%"}
![Life Cycle of *Strongyloides stercoralis* (Credit: [CDC](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/strongyloidiasis/index.html))](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/strongyloidiasis/modules/Strongyloides_LifeCycle_19.jpg?_=51499)
:::
::::

::: {.notes}
- L3 infectious stage
- Penetrate skin, migration via lungs, mouth, intestine
- Migration trace: exposure to chitin (material of cuticula)
  - trigger: transcription of IL-33
:::

## Immune Response agianst Helminth Infection {style="font-size: 1.4rem;"}

| **Timeline** | **Infection Stage** | **Immune Response** |
| --- | ------- | --------- |
| Day 0 | - L3 infectious stage <br>- Penetrate skin | |
| Day 2 | - Migrate via skin, lung, to mouth. <br>- Invasion by swallow. | - Eosinophilc and neutrophilic granulocytes.<br>- Fast mast cell degranulation promoted by IL-9. |
| Day 5 | - Reach intestine. <br>- Moult to adult.  | - Fast mast cell degranulation promoted by IL-9. |
| Week 2 | | - Adaptive immune system established. <br>- Production of IgE and IgG, conventional activation of mast cell. |
| Week 3-4 | | - Full eradication. |
| Post-infection | | - Semi-resistant to subsequent infections |

- Mast cell-deficient mice are unable to terminate infections.

```{r}
show_pathway(1, 'style="font-size: 1.8rem;"')
```

## IL-33 triggers rapid parasite expulsion

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
- HpARI binds IL-33 to DNA (tether), block its receptor (ST2).
  - IL-33 inhibitor (HpARI) increases parasite abundance.
- IL-33 effect promotion: i.n. rec. IL-33 application / CCP 1/2 stabilizes IL-33 and amplifies its effect.
  - Significant difference between control (PBS) and IL-33 application / IL-33 stabilization.
:::
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](assets/images/IL-33-sig.png)
:::
::::

## Activated mast cell excutes the extensive expulsion

:::: {.columns}
::: {.column width="60%"}
- mMCPT-1 (mast cell protease 1) reflects to which extent the mucosal mast cells have degranulated, measured with qPCR
:::
::: {.column width="40%"}
![](assets/images/IL-33_mMCPT.png)
:::
::::


## Rapid activation in early stage by IL-9

- Target of *S. ratti* infection strategy
  - Surpressing IL-9 mediated mast cell activation
    - Induction of Treg expansion [@blankenhaus2011]
    - Induction of negative regulatory receptors (BTLA) [@breloer2015]
- IL-33 mediated IL-9 production by ILC2

```{r}
show_pathway(3)
```

## IL-33

- Tissue-derived nuclear cytokine (alarmin)
- ST2 receptor
- Expressed majorly in endothelial cells, epithelial cells, fibroblast-like cells.

